title: Friday, 21st October, 2016

11:12 am

PM

Northern Trust

PM

Burberry's results give a chance to see trends developing across the luxury space, such as the effects of currency moves on regional luxury demand. Overall comparable sales in the Retail segment were flat. Within this the UK showed 2Q comp sales up by 30%. Outside the UK, Europe remains weak with some growth in domestic demand 'more than offset by declines in tourist spend'. Mainland China improved with mid single-digit growth in the quarter, despite upgrades to the Beijing store portfolio. HK still suffers from negative footfall with comp sales down a double-digit percentage. The Americas suffered from 'uneven' domestic demand and a double-digit decline in the travelling luxury customer.

11:12 am
PM

Elsewhere, on a stock-specific basis, wholesale revenues were down by 14% underlying (-6% as reported) on brand elevation strategies and tighter inventory control by wholesale customers. Licensing revenues fell by 54% underlying on the expiry of Japanese Burberry licenses. These were both in-line with expectations. Overall guidance for adjusted PBT is unchanged, and results were in-line with expectations but given the substantial run it has had - it's re-rated from 15 to 18x in a matter of months – we think it could easily pull back to its average of about 17x. It's still above levels where we turned a little more constructive on it (having ejected from QCC earlier in year) but clearly need more time to see the turnaround story in action.

PM

Liberum straight out sellers

PM

Following Burberry's H1/Q2 trading announcement we update our forecasts and target price to reflect recent FX moves. Previous guidance was for a £90m gain from FX tailwinds for FY 2017 PBT. This was updated to £125m on current spot rates and we have reflected this in our new forecasts. We view FX related upgrades as relatively low quality and note that the company has not changed its guidance for underlying PBT, excluding FX. Growth remains low in the sector context and the valuation is at a premium. We upgrade our TP to 1075p from 975p but maintain our SELL rating.

11:24 am
PM

BAT's offer to Reynolds was perhaps inevitable at some stage, though the
timing certainly was a surprise to us. Given the current levels of
indebtedness it means a rather higher equity proportion (57%) but then again
tobacco equity valuations are higher than at any time before while interest
rates are low. At 14x FY17E EBITDA the proposed deal multiple is higher
than the historical industry average of 12x.

PM

The deal looks mid-single digits accretive based on $400m of synergies and
assuming a cost of debt at 3% (note ABI borrowed 3.3% to buy SAB). That
accretion flows to the dividend too give the group's 65% payout ratio. It is
rather more accretive to free cash flow per share (high single digits) replacing
42% of Reynolds dividends with 100% of its free cash flow. On a pro-forma
basis, we estimate the transaction leaves BAT's FY17E net debt-to-EBITDA
at c3.5x.

PM

US tobacco market certainly looks one of the most attractive profit pools right
now, cigarettes being very affordable, a balanced market, while Reynolds
has arguably the most attractive portfolio of brands post the Lorillard merger.

11:25 am
PM

Consolidation has been a theme in tobacco for a decade or more and BAT's
approach to Reynolds has the look of the beginning of the end game. Are a
PMI/Altria reunion and a JT/Imperial tie-up the last 2 logical steps? Multiples
have been creeping up too with BAT offering 14x CY17E EBITDA for
Reynolds (Imperial trades on 12x CY17E today).

PM

What do we think of Japan Tobacco / Imps?

PM

Japan Tobacco has been about to buy one of the UK majors since the very first day I become a market reporter

Dear Izabella,

Please join Dario Perkins for a conference call at 15:00 (UK time) on Wednesday 26th October where he will answer questions on major macro drivers such as :

· Will inflation taken over from deflation in 2017?
· Could we see another taper tantrum in bond markets, or worse a repeat of 1994?
· Can central banks do anything to manage these risks (e.g. Japanese-style yield targeting)
· How vulnerable are asset prices to rising yields?

PM

There's more on Sky after this capital markets day yesterday

PM

And it's not all positive

11:39 am
PM

Steve Liechti at Investec placed the stock under review

PM

Reluctantly

PM

CMD yesterday underpins our view that Sky is a formidable operator and we see the shares -4% yesterday as harsh. Scale and content leverage plus best practice integration were plus points. However, we remain at a fundamental Reduce with no new catalyst to change our view of increasing long-term pressure on investment returns/growth. The good news is that Mobile cost is within consensus, but so is sales – implying no step change to growth and possibly some give elsewhere in our long-term revenue assumptions. PT U/R.

11:40 am
PM

CEO big picture – Sky operates in changing markets and grows despite this, given innovation plus leverage of its brand/customer relationship and strong content. The company has scaled geographically and via new product categories, shifting the sales mix beyond 'old' UK pay TV – 1/3 of 10-year sales growth from non-subscription, but subs are still 85% of FY16 sales. Broader offerings imply more to go for – accessing advertising, transactional, programme sales and mobile plays to £60bn markets; double ‘just’ pay TV.
Financial targets – Mid to high single-digit growth sales target with UK mid-single digit (as f/c but low end), Italy low single-digit (as f/c) and Germany double-digit (we look conservative here with high single-digit). We forecast FY17-19E +5%/year. Programme costs should grow in line with sales (content is the key driver) with operating cost target growth +1-2% via efficiencies/scale, implying a better EBITA margin – we f/c FY17E 11.4% to FY19E 13.5%. Reiterated £400m sales cost target savings by 2020 with more specific project detail, though 2020 is the next UK FPL Premier League cost step up year.
Cash flow – Capex has peaked post fall-off of Europe integration costs and HQ development. Priority now is debt pay-down, dividends then possible further shareholder return. M&A, e.g. new territories, downplayed. We f/c FY17E net cash inflow of £253m then £500-600m/year in FY18/19E.
Mobile - Ready to launch with pre-registrations targeted for end of October and price/tariff reveal pre-Christmas and full market launch in NY. The good news is that £35m capex is in FY16/17 guidance as is the P&L launch cost. The bad news is that expected sales are within current guidance, so no growth uplift.

PM

Nothing on Kodi sticks, mind

11:44 am

He's using Equities First Holdings for this

Now, you may remember that EFH were the guys who got dragged in to the Quindell affair

PM

But you can see from this announcement that they've learnt a lesson from that

11:45 am
PM

There's full dislcosure of the terms here for Truell

PM

Disruptive Capital Investments Limited ("DCIL") is entering into a financing arrangement with Equities First Holdings LLC ("EFH"). Under the terms of the facility, DCIL has transferred 6,000,000 Tungsten shares to EFH as collateral.

DCIL's interests remain aligned with those of other shareholders and the EFH arrangement is such that DCIL remains fully financially and economically exposed to Tungsten's share price. Whilst DCIL has transferred title to the shares for the period of the facility, EFH have warranted that they will refrain from short selling and will not exercise any voting or other such consensual rights or powers under the terms of the agreement. Strategic voting rights will be exercised in collaboration with DCIL.

As a result of this arrangement, for the period of the facility DCIL has an interest in the voting rights attaching to 11,451,988 Ordinary shares representing 9.1 per cent of the issued ordinary share capital of the Company.

PM

This is to be encouraged, no?

11:46 am

11:57 am
IK

From PD at UBS:

IK

The first rule of Fight Club is you don't talk about tapering. The second rule of Fight Club is you DO NOT talk about tapering. The ECB did not talk about tapering. The ECB did not talk about talking about tapering. The ECB will probably taper its quantitative policy.

IK

The third rule of Fight Club is if you go limp, the fight is over. The UK's prime minister meets one of the many presidents of Europe on the fringes of the EU leaders' summit, and it is extremely unlikely that either side is going to demonstrate anything other than steely determination.

11:57 am
IK

The fourth rule of Fight Club is two guys to a fight. The US presidential election race continues. Actually, markets are now focusing their interest on Congress as the balance of Congress is likely to determine the extent to which the presidential policy agenda is carried out.

IK

Out of the combat arenas of policy and politics we have an improvement in UK consumer confidence (on a little-watched survey), and the Eurozone's survey of professional forecasters. The latter may be more accurate as a guide to economic reality than surveys of businesses and consumers.

IK

Mario Draghi: Jedi Master
